message.content: We refer to guidelines from the American Cancer Society for help. The guidelines state that the decision to screen for prostate cancer should be based on shared decision-making between the patient and the physician, taking into account the patient's individual risk factors and preferences. In this case, the patient is older and has a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia and percutaneous coronary angioplasty, which may increase his risk of complications from screening and treatment. Therefore, it is appropriate to discuss the risks and benefits of screening with the patient and inform him that no screening test is recommended unless he expresses a strong preference for it.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The US Preventive Services Task Force recommends against routine PSA-based screening for prostate cancer in men age 70 and older. The patient is 71, and therefore no screening test is recommended. Ultrasonography alone is not recommended as a screening test for prostate cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The US Preventive Services Task Force recommends against routine prostate cancer screening with either PSA testing or digital rectal examination (DRE) in men aged 70 years or older. Therefore, option D is the most appropriate answer. Option A is not recommended for routine screening, and option B and C are no longer recommended for routine screening in older men as their life expectancy is shorter and the risks of screening and treatment may outweigh the benefits.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Current guidelines from the American Cancer Society do not recommend routine PSA testing for men with a life expectancy less than 10 years, as the benefits of screening this population are unclear. The patient in this case is 71 years old and has multiple comorbidities, suggesting that he may have a limited life expectancy. Therefore, no screening test is recommended.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Current guidelines do not recommend routine PSA screening for men over the age of 70 with a life expectancy of less than 10 years, especially in the setting of comorbidities such as coronary artery disease. Therefore, the most appropriate answer is D, no screening test is recommended. Annual prostate ultrasonography is not recommended for screening in asymptomatic men, and serum PSA testing every year is not necessary. Serum PSA testing every 2-4 years may be considered in men with a life expectancy greater than 10 years who are at higher risk for prostate cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The US Preventative Services Task Force recommends against PSA-based screening for prostate cancer in men over the age of 70. The patient is already on medication for benign prostatic hyperplasia, and the risk of harm from prostate cancer screening may outweigh the benefits in this patient. Therefore, no screening test is recommended.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The US Preventive Services Task Force recommends against PSA screening for prostate cancer in men age 70 and older who have no signs or symptoms of the disease. Therefore, no screening test is recommended for this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The USPSTF recommends against PSA-based screening for prostate cancer in men aged 70 years and older. As the patient is 71 years old, no screening test is recommended. Prostate ultrasonography is not recommended for screening purposes either.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Current guidelines recommend against routine PSA screening in men over age 70, as the potential harms of over-diagnosis and over-treatment outweigh the benefits. Therefore, no screening test is recommended for this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The US Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommends against PSA-based screening for prostate cancer in men aged 70 years or older. Therefore, no screening test is recommended in this patient. Prostate ultrasonography is not recommended for routine screening. Serum PSA should only be done if the patient chooses to undergo screening and after a discussion of potential benefits and harms.
